Where col_sum[j] is the sum of the j-th column (all rows), and row_sum[i] is the sum of the i-th row (all columns). So if we precompute row_sums and col_sums, then for each cell (i,j), the neighbor sum can be computed quickly. That would be more efficient. Let's see:

         But this is manageable, since 26*26 cells, each with 50 neighbors → 26*26*50 = 33,800 operations, which is acceptable.

         So for each cell (i,j), we need to iterate over all possible neighbors and sum their counts.

         Alternatively, perhaps we can compute the sum more efficiently.

         // compute row and column sums

         int[] row_sums = new int[26];

         int[] col_sums = new int[26];

         for (int i = 0; i < 26; i++) {

             for (int j = 0; j < 26; j++) {

                 row_sums[i] += cnt[i][j];

                 col_sums[j] += cnt[i][j];

             }

         }

         long total = 0;

         for (int i = 0; i < 26; i++) {

             for (int j = 0; j < 26; j++) {

                 int current = cnt[i][j];

                 if (current == 0) continue;

                 int sum_neighbors = (col_sums[j] - current) + (row_sums[i] - current);

                 total += (long) current * sum_neighbors;

             }

         }

         ans = total / 2;
